text: Depression, paranoia, and OCD are all interconnected. OCD is about obsessions and compulsions, and paranoias are obsessive fears. Depression, OCD and paranoia are not themselves the problem. OCD is your mind's way of telling you that there is something wrong with your life.

The reason that you are obsessing and compulsing is that there is something about your life that isn't right but that you are not yet willing to face. There is one, and only one, way to get over OCD: to find a path in life that works for you. It is to do the thing that you truly want to do.

As long as you don't do the thing you truly want to do, you will be afflicted by OCD, paranoia and depression. Once you start doing that thing, you will still be obsessive-compulsive, because that is how your brain is wired, but your obsessive-compulsive tendencies will be an asset, not a liability. They will push you forward, as they did Beethoven, not hold you back.

Paranoias are your mind's way of telling you something. Superficially they may not seem sane, but you are picking up on something. Your paranoias are not, ultimately, paranoias. Paranoias are usually inverted and projected desires. One's 'paranoia' that so and so is stalking one is really a desire that so and so be paying attention to one.

As for depression, there is always a reason for it. The same thing that is making you obsessive compulsive is making you depressive: you are not living in a way that is true to who you are; you are selling yourself. Your OCD is about the instincts that you are suppressing bucking and pressing for discharge. Your depression is about the fact that those instincts are not being properly expressed in action.

You should see OCD, depression, and paranoia as being about almost but not quite having the life you want. They are all ways that frustrated urges are trying, without success, to express themselves. You should modify your life so that they can express themselves. See OCD not as a mental illness, but as slightly mis-directed mental health.

A bureaucrat is somebody who accepts whatever the institution that employs him wants him to accept. A bureaucrat does not believe anything. But a bureaucrat accepts what he is supposed to accept. Acceptance is not belief. Belief is a relation between subject and reality. Acceptance is a relation between subject and bureaucracy.

To have a conscience is to have moral beliefs; it is to believe that some things are right and other things are wrong. Since a bureaucrat does not believe anything, he does not have a conscience. And since he does not have a conscience, he does not have internal conflicts and therefore neither needs nor can possibly benefit from psychoanalysis.

A bureaucrat may have trouble accepting institutional truth. In other words, he may have trouble accepting the obvious lies that his institution requires him to accept. A bureaucrat may therefore need to figure out how to rationalize his acceptance of institutional lies.

An astrologer is somebody who helps people construct rationalizations and therefore helps people believe their own lies. Therefore, bureaucrats sometimes need astrologers. A psychoanalyst is somebody who helps people see through their own lies. Therefore, bureaucrats never need psychoanalysts. In fact, bureaucrats need psychoanalysts to be absent from their midst.

Autistic people seem to live in their own world, and the obvious thing to say about them is that they are self-contained. But they are not self-contained. They are pseudo-self-contained. Autism is about needing people early in life and being given trauma instead. The traumatized child reacts by withdrawing into himself.

The autistic person's withdrawal is not about being emotionally self-sufficient. It is about quite the opposite. It is about being so dependent on others that unless one is given just the right cocktail of emotional support from others, one hysterically flees into psychotic seclusion.

Being genuinely self-contained is about balance. It is about being given—or having been given—the right level, and the right kind of emotional sustenance from others and, on that basis, being able, like a dolphin that has taken in enough air or a camel that has taken in enough water, to go out on one's own. This is not what the autistic person is doing. Autism is a way of being damaged. True independence is about the opposite of being damaged.

A sign of true independence is flexibility, and rigidity is a sign of damage-based pseudo-independence. Bureaucrats are people who are damaged and have no free will. Bureaucrats need others to tell them what to do. And when they come across someone who is genuinely independent, they invidiously describe him as having 'autism' or 'Asperger's', sometimes going so far as to get psychiatrists to formally diagnose them in this way. But such characterizations are the opposite of the truth—and projective.
Chomsky's two contributions to philosophy are: (1) The poverty of stimulus argument for the existence of pre-experiential knowledge, and (2) His argument for the existence of sub-personal thought.

Poverty of stimulus argument: If you bombarded a rock, or a chair, or a tree with the same sounds and patterns of light that led to your being able to understand language, would it learn a language? No. Any given item of furniture in the house where you grew up was exposed to just the sort of optical and acoustical disturbances that, in you, led to the ability to use and understand language, yet it did not learn.

A dog or cat, if placed in circumstances just like those that led to your having the ability to understand language, cannot even acquire the most rudimentary linguistic competence, no matter how many noises or light-patterns of the appropriate kind it is bombarded with. People learn language and become so linguistically proficient on the basis of such a paucity of data, when other creatures cannot.

Because of your innate cognitive structure, you—unlike a cat or a dog, not to mention a rock or a tree—respond to those sounds and light-patterns in the right way. You derive knowledge from them. In you, but not in a cat or a dog or a tree, they trigger a constellation of responses that eventuate knowledge of a language.

The operative word is 'trigger.' If you did not ab initio all but know a language—if your cognitive structure were not already there, in a very developed state, just waiting for a little bit of experience to 'turn it on'—then no amount of sensory stimulation would do the trick. If the structure of your mind did not, as it were, anticipate or prefigure the linguistic knowledge currently embodied therein, then no amount of teaching or conditioning would have led to its having that knowledge.

It is your mind's innate structure that enables your mind to acquire linguistic ability and, by analogous reasoning, to acquire any of the various forms of cognitive competence of which it is now in possession. Since this pre-experiential structure is cognitive in nature, it follows that you have pre-experiential—or a priori—knowledge of truths on the basis of which you are able to organize experiences and distill their contents into various forms of cognitive competence.

The knowledge that Chomsky is talking about is not knowledge that your mind has; that knowledge is your mind. Knowledge that you have is knowledge that presupposes an existing cognitive structure. It is only if your mind is stocked with relevant categories and protocols that you are able to know what the capital of Delaware is or how Euclid proved there to be infinitely many primes. Knowledge that you learn is structure-internal. It is internal to your existing cognitive structure.

The a priori knowledge that Chomsky is talking about is not internal to your cognitive framework: it is your cognitive framework. You are not aware of it, because it itself is your awareness. Your knowledge that Wilmington is the capital of Delaware, or that root-2 is irrational, is the object of your awareness. The cognitive framework that enables you to have such knowledge is the subject to which that object is thereby known.

You are aware of yourself—in the sense that you are aware of many of the feelings, thoughts, etc. created by your cognitive architecture. But all of the mental contents that you are aware of are occupants of that architecture. The feeling of sadness that you are now consciously experiencing will come and go. Yesterday, it didn't exist; now it does; tomorrow, once more, it won't. But you will be there all the same.

All of your knowledge of your sensations, perceptions, beliefs, deliberations is knowledge of the contents of your cognitive framework. The things known are to your mind itself what the occupants of a hotel are to the hotel. The hotel is one thing; its occupants are quite another. The structure of the hotel imposes strict and rigidly defined limits on the way in which people in the hotel can move about and interact.

Our cognitive structure can be deduced from our thought-patterns. But those thoughts, perceptions, and feelings are not themselves that structure. They are its productions. They are to that structure what a car factory is to the cars it produces.

When you are, as we say, 'aware of yourself', the thing you are aware of is not, strictly speaking, your self. It is not your cognitive framework itself. Rather, it is some product of that framework. The knowledge underlying the knowledge that you are aware of—the knowledge that Chomsky is discussing, the knowledge that is your cognitive framework, rather than being a product of it—that is not the object of any instance of these misleadingly so-called cases of 'self'-awareness.

This is why the framework-constitutive structures and operations that mediate your learning and using language, and that mediate other forms of cognitive competence, are, to use Chomsky's term, deeply unconscious, unlike the contents of the Freudian unconscious, which are unconscious, but not deeply so.

Languages are both productive, meaning that linguistic expressions can be combined into larger expressions, and systematic, meaning that the parts composing complex expressions can be re-arranged to form other complex expressions. Given that we use and understand language, it follows that the systematicity and productivity of language are reflections of corresponding facts about our cognitive structure. Language is productive and systematic because our minds are productive and systematic.

We can combine sentences that we understand into larger sentences that we understand, and we can re-arrange the constituents of sentences that we understand into new sentences that we also understand, because we understand the relations of logical dependence that map the meanings of sentence-parts onto those of the sentences thereby composed.

Obviously these cognitive abilities are mediated or implemented by physiology—by 'wetware' of some kind or other. And obviously all knowledge, whether pre- or post-experiential, is encoded in brain-structures of some kind or other, the same being true of all aptitudes.

If we were dealing with pure physiology—as opposed to physiology that encoded insight and intelligence, that embodied an understanding of interrelations of logical dependence and of content-appropriateness—if that were the case, then experience, supposing we were even able to have it in the first place, would enable us only to respond to situations in a few stereotyped ways: we would not have the ability to keep pace, in our thoughts or therefore our deeds, with novelty.

Where there is pure physiology, as opposed to physiology that mediates intelligence, there can be training, but there cannot be teaching. There can be operant conditioning but there cannot be genuine learning. The fact that we can use language in the ways in which we can use it—and the very fact that we can learn it in the first place—is proof that these pre-experiential structural properties of ours are not physiological, but are rather cognitive in nature.
